instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.A1708: What is A1708? A1708 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2017, 2016 with EMC 3164, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00840, 820-00875..
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.3V3_G3H: What is 3V3_G3H? This is one of the first power rails that must turn on for Macbooks that use USB-C for charging. This power rail powers the CD3215 chip that controls the USB-C charger, speaks to the USB-C charger, and requests 20 volts up from the default 5 volts that the USB-C charger puts out when initially connected to an unknown device. .
definitions.R7020: What is R7020? Current sense shunt resistor for the charger, the resistors between this and the ISL6259 should be proper rating or else machine will turn off the charger. Measuring pins 27/28 on ISL6259 should give you 20.02 ohms. .
definitions.C7050: What is C7050? Capacitor between current sense lines on ISL6259 chip for battery current sensing, you should measure around 2.202 ohms across this. Often when the resistance across this capacitor is higher it is because one of the current sense resistors going to the ISL6259 chip has failed. When current sensing resistors between the shunt resistor and the ISL6259 power IC have failed the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being sent to or drawn from the battery, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing/sending power to the battery as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR: What is PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR? This is the input that comes from the charger..
definitions.PPVBAT_G3H_CHGR_REG: What is PPVBAT_G3H_CHGR_REG? This is battery power that flows to the system AFTER it has gone through a current sense resistor, before it goes through a fuse to become PPBUS_G3H power rail. .
definitions.SMBUS_BATT_SCL: What is SMBUS_BATT_SCL? SMBUS_BATT_SCL is the clock line of an I2C data line between the battery charging chip that creates PPBUS_G3H, the system management controller(SMC), the battery, and the battery indicator LED..
definitions.SMBUS_BATT_SDA: What is SMBUS_BATT_SDA? SMBUS_BATT_SDA is the data line of an I2C data line between the battery charging chip that creates PPBUS_G3H, the system management controller(SMC), the battery, and the battery indicator LED..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A  No boot
threads.message:
This Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>   A820-00840 Came in today  customer stated that some water spilled on it , it was working then suddenly shut down. So I inspected the board and found no water damaged wheresoever on the board  , as I connected  amp meter i am getting 20v but nothing else , I proceeded get the motherboard out to test and found diode mode readings are fine but <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 0.111V I checked <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> For short and all was good I checked F7000 in continuity mode and it was fine and in diode mode 0.404 ohms , I have also checked <CHIP>U6990</CHIP> for short and all diode mode readinds are fine but -<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>  is 0.111V 

May I please get some help?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A  No boot
threads.message:
USB-C power inputs switch to 20V without <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>???
That's very strange; was the battery disconnected?

Test the board alone on the desk, only charger connected.
Do you get 20V at <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A  No boot
threads.message: Sorry I Have made a mistake regarding the <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>   , this power rail is ok i am getting the 3.73V when USB -C is connected  and also getting 20V  at <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR> with battery disconnected  but still <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is not present.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A  No boot
threads.message:
Change them directly if you have  scrap boards.
In fact, I never found bad <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR>/40, but few times I saw <TRANSISTOR>Q3100</TRANSISTOR>/200 failing.
In your case, <TRANSISTOR>Q3100</TRANSISTOR>/200 should be good if power ports switch to 20V.

As general rule, Gate pin of MOSFET must show OL (diode mode) with any other pin; measured out of board!
Source-Drain should measure like a diode (silicium).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A  No boot
threads.message: Ok , Then  You suggest that I change <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR>/<TRANSISTOR>Q7040</TRANSISTOR> which I did last night both of them  just to see if the behaviour would change but the result remained the same I am not too sure if <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> is my culprit , I was going to simply remove it by a new one to see if I get a boot , let me know if you suggest me to do so .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A  No boot
threads.message: I have changed  <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR>/<TRANSISTOR>Q7040</TRANSISTOR>   to newer ones  but still not ok , but there s something that i found here , I have another known good board that i am comparing the values with , on my know good board <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> resistance value in diode is is 0.287ohms  and on the board that  i am trying to repair it's 0.408 ohms which I found too high and If I try to look for short using 3v on the DCSP there s no consumption wheresover.  Do you suggest that i change directly  <TRANSISTOR>Q3100</TRANSISTOR>/200? I am thinking that they are doing ok since i am getting my 20V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A  No boot
threads.message:
Don't touch USB-C area, if you get 20V!

How can you suspect a short, when you get higher reading to ground???
BTW, is strange to mention "resistance value" in diode mode; don't write "ohm" after diode mode reading (nor V).
Diode mode readings to ground differ if on that rail is connected a Schottky diode, or not.

You should always compare diode mode readings on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> power rail in reverse mode too; black probe connected to ground.

Check diode mode to ground at SCL/SDA lines of battery bus.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A  No boot
threads.message: Ok , I agree , Let me do that , I do not touch the USB-C area at all .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A  No boot
threads.message:
I have taken my time to check entirely all the power lines of <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> from a known good board to compare with the one that i am repairing ,this is a very small report of the lines that i found in diode mode too low and some others too high 

<SIGNAL>TBA_GATE</SIGNAL> Q4 on the good board I have in diode mode 0.750 and on the bad one i am getting 0.719
<SIGNAL>PPBAT_G3H_CHGR_REG</SIGNAL> on good board diode mode is 0.273 and on bad board  0.405
<SIGNAL>TBA_CSOR_P</SIGNAL> good board  = 0.273 and bad board is 0.405
<SIGNAL>PPVIN_G3H_CHGR</SIGNAL> Good board =0.449  and bad board is 0.519
<SIGNAL>TBA_CSOR_N</SIGNAL> good board is 0.272 and bad board is 0.405
<SIGNAL>TBA_LX2</SIGNAL> good board is 0.337 and bad board is 0.302
<SIGNAL>TBA_GATE_Q1</SIGNAL> good board is 0.751 and bad board is 0.715

I am not sure if that could give us an idea of why some of those lines are high and other ones a little lower , the other lines that i did not mention are all  equal values comparing the good board to the bad one.
I hope that it is not a inner layer issue , the customer reported that before the macbook went off completely it was going off then turn back on by itself  after the water spilled on it but the board is intact no sign of water on the board at all.
Please help me out .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A  No boot
threads.message:
Board has been affected for liquid somewhere, for sure.
Change <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> before continue.

I have asked you an idea regarding the original <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> chip with the marking 9239HI and the one I purchased 9239CO if they make a difference , I have also reballed 3 different <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> from donor boards and no luck at all, I got the new ones with marking 9239CO let me know if they work the same.

I don't remember to done such a swap; it should work, I think.

Check <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> with both charger and battery connected.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A  No boot
threads.message:
A very quick update , I think that i got the issue figured out , What I did at last i used my thermal imager to scan anything for short , and i found right next to <CHIP>U2800</CHIP> right above it which is not even mention on the schematics neither the board view but the Markings on that chip is PI3U5B32 looking like a voltage regulator right beside the back of the magsafe it is  so i removed and replaced it and Boom I got a boot , it is now charging pulling 33.8 Watts and 1.78 Amps 
Iam keeping an eye on it as during the process i had to replace that chip twice and the second one is the one working now , so i also had to replace <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> As the 9239CO was not working .

I will keep on monitoring it if anything I will let you know , thank you for now for keeping up with me in everything step of the way , I really appreciate it 

.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A  No boot
threads.message: Sorry for so much of typos , I meant in every step of the way , my apologies .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A  No boot
threads.message:
USB redriver chip fails a lot on these boards; many threads about it on the forum.
But is first time when someone found it bad when USB power ports switch to 20V; really strange.
We have to note this issue; thanks for feedback.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A  No boot
threads.message:
It really Is , I am keeping an  eye on it to see if  There will be any side affects it shows that it is charging but not showing the battery percentage as customer did not provide the password to unlock it .So let's keep an eye on it , I think some of those issues can also be detected via Thermal camera as they do provide heat.

Thanks again I will keep you in the loop if it's fully working.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A  No boot

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A  No boot
threads.message:
No need to replace them, if you changed with equivalent.

You can find lot of information on Internet (including videos), about how to create preinstalled macOS pendrive.
Be aware, is not easy to find good pendrives; many of times are too slow, even being marked as USB 3.1  :(.
Better to use an SSD with SATA to USB 3.1 adapter.

I tried to disconnect  the charger and its staying on .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A  No boot
threads.message: Now I just shut the  macbook down and I disconnected the USB charger, the battery is charged at 69% but as soon as i power it on without the USB charger connected , it boots half way with the apple logo than power off , then when i press the power button it would ask me to connect the charger, what do you suggest  in that case , Can a bad battery does that?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A  No boot
threads.message: You should test with known good battery, if want to discard it.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A  No boot
threads.message: I was able to get a hold of the passcode and indeed the system is saying that the battery needs replacement , therefore I informed the customer and he stated Yes he s well aware of that so i am getting a new replacement battery to complete the repair process, Thank you so very much .
